explanation:
OS_NetworkGetID_Impl: The target function delegates all work to OS_NetworkGetID_Impl. To determine whether the overall behavior violates the MISRA for-loop rule you must inspect the implementation of OS_NetworkGetID_Impl (it may contain for-loops). The rule treats the behaviour of a for-loop as including any functions called from within the loop body, so the body of OS_NetworkGetID_Impl (and any functions it calls) must be examined for: loop counters, loop-control flags, side effects in the second clause, modifications of loop counters in the body or third clause, use of objects modified in the loop body in the loop expressions, and any called functions that themselves modify loop counters or other objects used in loop control. 

Note: If OS_NetworkGetID_Impl has additional callees, those callees (and any global variables, macros, typedefs, or inline functions they use) must also be provided because the MISRA rule requires analyzing the behaviour of functions invoked inside a for-loop body.
